facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 284 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 284 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 21, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Rewa, in Misc. Civil Writ No. 27 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Rewa, in Misc. Civil Writ No. 27 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant was holder of a permit to run stage carriage on Rewa-Singrauli route in Vindhya Pradesh, merged in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the holder of a permit to run a stage carriage on a stretch of the public highway called the Rewa- Singrauli route, in the State of Vindhya Pradesh which is number merged in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Appellant's permit was due to expire on December 11, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: That permit was due to expire on December 11, 1955, and so on September 12, 1955, he made an application for its renewal for a further period.

facts.text: Appellant applied for renewal of permit on September 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: That permit was due to expire on December 11, 1955, and so on September 12, 1955, he made an application for its renewal for a further period.

facts.text: Respondent Anant Prasad made a representation against renewal of appellant's permit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Anant Prasad who will be referred to as the respondent, made a representation against the renewal of the appellants permit.

facts.text: Respondent Anant Prasad applied for grant of the permit.

anchor.surface_text: He also applied for the grant of the permit to himself.

facts.text: State Transport Authority, Vindhya Pradesh, ordered on December 9, 1955: 'Renewed for three years'.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1955, the State Transport Authority, Vindhya Pradesh, made an order in the following terms Renewed for three years .

facts.text: The order of STA meant appellant's permit was renewed for three years; not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the order meant that the appellants permit was renewed for three years.

facts.text: No express order was made on respondent's application for permit.

anchor.surface_text: No express order was made on the respondents application for the grant of the permit to him.

facts.text: Respondent preferred appeal against STA order to Vindhya Pradesh Transport Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal against this order to the Vindhya Pradesh Transport Appellate Tribunal, the appellate authority under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended before Tribunal that appeal was not competent.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended by the appellant before the Appellate Tribunal that the appeal was number companypetent.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal rejected contention, cancelled appellant's permit, issued permit to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal rejected this companytention and passed an order cancelling the Permit granted to the appellant by the State Transport Authority and issuing the permit to the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant moved Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, for writ of certiorari quashing Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, for a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Appellate Tribunal on the ground that it disclosed an error on the face of it

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner held appeal was competent and dismissed the writ application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner held that the appeal was companypetent and dismissed the application for the writ.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on April 21, 1959 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. April 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-This appeal arises out of an application for a writ of certiorari

facts.text: Respondent was aggrieved by refusal to grant permit under cl. a of s.64.

anchor.surface_text: He had applied for a permit and had number got it. He was therefore a person aggrieved by the refusal to grant a permit and clearly came within cl.  a .

facts.text: No express refusal to respondent but effect of order was refusal as permit granted to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the order of the State Transport Authority did number expressly refuse him the permit. But that numberdoubt was the effect of the order that was made.

facts.text: Vindhya Pradesh merged in State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: in the State of Vindhya Pradesh which is number merged in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Appellant contended that fresh applications could not be considered till renewal objections disposed.

anchor.surface_text: When there are a number of applications in respect of the same permit, one of which is by way of renewal to which objections have been filed and the others, fresh applications, the latter companyld number be taken up

facts.text: Court held STA had jurisdiction to consider respondent's application along with renewal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore unable to hold that in the present case the 88 State Transport Authority had numberjurisdiction to companysider the respondents application or to make any order in respect of it

facts.text: Respondent not a person contemplated by cl. e or f of s.64; admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the respondent was number a person companytemplated by cl.  e  of the section. It is also number in dispute that he was number one of those mentioned in cl.  f .

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal is prescribed authority under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the Vindhya Pradesh Transport Appellate Tribunal, the appellate authority under the Act.

facts.text: Only one permit could be granted on the route.

anchor.surface_text: There was only one permit which companyld be granted and the result of the order was to give it to the appellant.

issues.text: Did an appeal lie to the Appellate Tribunal from the order made by the State Transport Authority in the present case?

anchor.surface_text: The question is, Did an appeal lie to the Appellate Tribunal from the order made by the State Transport Authority in the present case ?

issues.text: Was the respondent a person aggrieved by the refusal to grant a permit so as to have a right of appeal under clause (a) of Section 64?

anchor.surface_text: He had applied for a permit and had number got it. He was therefore a person aggrieved by the refusal to grant a permit and clearly came within cl. a .

arguments.court_reasoning: Clauses independent; cl.(f) does not restrict cl.(a); effective appeal requires full powers; distinguishes Dholpur case.

arguments.claim: Clauses of s.64 are independent; cl.(f) does not render cl.(a) infructuous or restrict appellate powers in cl.(a) appeal.

holdings.text: The respondent was a person aggrieved by the refusal to grant a permit and clearly came within clause (a) of Section 64.

anchor.surface_text: He had applied for a permit and had number got it. He was therefore a person aggrieved by the refusal to grant a permit and clearly came within cl. a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent applied for permit but did not receive it; grant to rival applicant constitutes refusal under cl.(a).

holdings.text: The effect of granting the permit to the appellant was a refusal to the respondent, making the appeal competent under Section 64(a).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the order of the State Transport Authority did number expressly refuse him the permit. But that numberdoubt was the effect of the order that was made. He had made an application for the grant of the permit to him and the application was disposed of without granting him the permit but granting it to a companypeting applicant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express order needed; only one permit available, grant to one implies refusal to other; follows S. Gopala Reddi precedent.

holdings.text: Sections 47, 57 and 58 do not require disposal of renewal application before considering fresh applications; renewal applications must be heard together with new ones.

anchor.surface_text: We think this companytention companypletely lacks substance. [...] We are therefore unable to hold that in the present case the State Transport Authority had numberjurisdiction to companysider the respondents application or to make any order in respect of it

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.47 silent on order; S.57(3),(5) allows simultaneous hearing; S.58 treats renewal as new application, requires preference only if considered together.

holdings.text: Clauses of Section 64 are independent; clause (f) does not restrict appeals or powers under clause (a).

anchor.surface_text: But this clause cannot be companystrued in a manner so as to render infructuous another clause in the same section. Nor do we find anything in cl. f to justify such a companystruc- tion. The different clauses in the section deal with different situations. Each is independent of the others.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction prevents rendering cl.(a) infructuous; each clause covers distinct situations without limiting others.

holdings.text: In a competent appeal under clause (a) of Section 64, the appellate authority has full powers to set aside a renewal or grant order and provide relief.

anchor.surface_text: If an appeal lies under any of the other clauses, that of companyrse must be an effective appeal and the appellate authority must therefore have all powers to give the relief to which the appellant is found entitled. [...] there is numberhing in the Act to prevent the Appellate Tribunal from setting aside the order of the State Transport Authority renewinu the appellants permit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Effective appeal requires full relief; cl.(f) irrelevant to cl.(a) powers; distinguishes Dholpur case as no objection filed there but cl.(f) not restrictive; approves S. Gopala Reddi.

precedents.case_name: Dholpur Co-operative Transport Etc. Union Ltd. v. The Appellate Authority, Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: appellate authority cannot cancel permit granted to another unless foundation laid under cl. f
precedents.cited_holding: Where an appeal has been made under cl. a against the refusal of a permit, the Appellate Authority will generally have the right to give relief to the appellant by the grant of a permit, but will number have any jurisdiction to cancel the permit granted to another person, unless a foundation has been laid before the Regional Transport Authority for an appeal provided by cl. f by an objection of somebody entitled to appeal under that clause.

precedents.cited_proposition: clauses a and f of s.64 apply to different situations and do not restrict appellate powers
precedents.cited_holding: s. 64, sub-sees. a and f are intended in our opinion to apply to different situations and that the power of the appellate authority is number restricted in any manner either by the provisions of s. 64 or by any of the rules made under the powers companyferred by the Act

precedents.case_name: S. Gopala Reddi v. Regional Transport Authority, North Arcot
precedents.cited_proposition: appeal under cl. a competent even if involves attacking renewal order; sets at large the entire order
precedents.cited_holding: The appeal was, in our opinion, perfectly competent as an appeal against the order of the Regional Transport Authority, refusing to grant a permit. The fact that such an appeal involved an attack on the order granting a renewal of a permit to the 4th respondent would number prevent the appeal being what it was, viz., an appeal against a refusal to grant a permit, to the appellant.
